page.title: 02The Malmesbury Commoners
page.content: There are 285{Commoners}in Malmesbury, all descendants of men who fought for{King Athelstan}at the {Battle of Brunanburg in 937 AD. Athelstan, the Saxon King of Wessex, gave the men of Malmesbury a share of 700 acres of land}as a reward for their part in the defeat of the Danes. They could farm or graze animals on this land. The right to become a Commoner was passed down from father to son, and a ceremony is still held when a Malmesburian becomes a Commoner. He has to stand on a piece of turf from the common and is hit on the back with a hazel stick while someone says{"Turf and twig I give {to thee, as King Athelstan gave to {me."}He then receives a share of the annual rent on the land, but ceases to be a Commoner if he moves out of Malmesbury.
